E.l. Structural Drills. Four phase drill, as you did previously.
E.2. You are now going to hear a sentence followed by a cue
e.g. well, sick, small, or big. Make up your own statements like this: You'll hear:
Listen to the correct response, and repeat, etc. Off you go.

We shall now give you a model, and a cue that may be either this man, that near child, or the child and so on, or it can be a word such as well, or sick, or big, or small. It is up to you to put them in their appropriate place. We'll start off simply. The confirmation will be given as usual, please repeat it. Join in as you understand: Model.
F. Translate into the language. Four phase drill as before.

Conversion from singular to plural, demonstrative, You are asked to change from "this" to "these". Like this:
Listen for the correct response and repeat it. Off you go.

This is a drill in which you will be given a cue that may be either "this", "this man", "I", "those men" , "the man", and so on; or it may be a change from "is tired" to "is tall" and so on. Have fun!
C. Repeat the following phrases and sentences:
D. Repeat the sentences you've just heard and listen to their English meanings. Fix them in your mind.
"Are you well? Yes. I am well."
"Are you tired? Yes, I am tired."
"Are you happy? Yes, I am happy."
"Are you two well? Yes, we are well."
"Are you two tired? Yes, we are tired."
"Are you two happy? Yes we are happy."
"Are you well? Yes, we are well."
"Are you tired? Yes, we are tired."
"Are you happy? Yes, we are happy."
"Is this child well? Yes, it is well."
"Is this child tired? Yes, it is tired."
"Is this child happy? Yes, it is happy."
"Are you sick? No, I am well."
"Are you sick? No, I am not sick."
"Are you tired? No, I am not tired."
"Are you happy? No, I am not happy."
"Are you two sick? No, we are well."
"Are you two sick? No, we are not sick."
"Are you two tired? No, we are not tired."
"Are you two happy? No, we are not happy."
"Is the child sick? No, the child is well."
"Is the child sick? No, the child is not sick."
"Is the man tired? No, the man is not tired."
"Is the woman happy? No, the woman is not happy."
"Is this man sick? No, he is well."
"Is this man sick? No, he is not sick."
"Is that (near) child tired? No, it is not tired."
"Is that (far) woman happy? No, she is not happy."
E. Drills You will hear a question in the language. Answer in the affirmative, like this:
Now answer similar questions in the negative, using wiya.
F. Translate into the Language. Four phase drill.

D. Now repeat these sentences again and listen to their English meanings:
Substitutions. You will hear a model followed by a cue. Use the cue to make your new sentence. Four phase drill as usual.
Conversions from present to past tense. You'll hear a statement in the present tense. Answer in the past tense and listen for the correct response. Repeat the correct response.

These drills use short forms of the personal pronouns. Change from present to future as you did before.
Future tense. This time you are asked to change the subject of the sentence. Like this:
Transformations. You are now asked to combine two statements into one. Like this:
Confirmation and repeats as usual. Off you go.
As before, only that this time the subjects in the two sentences to be combined will be complex, like this:
That far big kangaroo will come.

This is a lesson of practice and consolidation. It does not follow the pattern of the previous lessons. First we hear the English version of a dialogue, which you then hear in Pitjantjatjara. Listen carefully.
B. Yes, I speak Pitjantjatjara. What about you?
A. Yes, I speak Pitjantjatjaraa little. Later on I'll speak a lot.
A. Yes, I am well. What about you?
B. I'm sick and I'm tired.
Now repeat the utterances of this dialogue one by one. Be careful to imitate the pronunciation and intonation exactly as the reader does it. Please listen to the dialogue once again. Do not repeat.
Now please listen to the dialogue once again. Do not repeat.
In this drill you will hear two sentences. Link them together like this: You'll hear:
meaning I am sick and I am tired.
"munu" is the equivalent of "and" in sentences of this type. Note that it takes the short form of the personal pronoun.
This sentence, meaning I am sick and I am tired, is to be converted into the you form (nyuntu) like this:
This dog is sick and tired
Later on I'll speak a lot.
No, I am sick and I am tired.
These men are well and happy.
We all will come and talk.
They are all short and small.
